utterance: When I was in Boston, I knew a feller, so he was a preticly friend of John Shullivan's. He is a Christian, that feller is, and yet the two of us lived like brothers. May I be unable to move from this spot if we did not. How, then, would you have it? Like here, in New York, where the Jews are a lot of greenhornsh and can not speak a word of English? Over there every Jew speaks English like a stream.
speaker: Jake
addressee: the presser and all the three women of the shop

utterance: Say, Dzake, John Sullivan is tzampion no longer, is he?
speaker: the presser

utterance: Oh, no! Not always is it holiday!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Why, don't you know? Jimmie Corbett leaked him, and Jimmie leaked Cholly Meetchel, too. You can betch you' bootsh! Johnnie could not leak Chollie, becaush he is a big bluffer, Chollie is,But Jimmie pundished him. Oh, didn't he knock him out off shight! He came near making a meat ball of him -with a chuckle. He tzettled him in three roynds. I knew a feller who had seen the fight.
speaker: Jake

utterance: What is a rawnd, Dzake?
speaker: the presser

utterance: Nice fun that! Fighting-like drunken moujiks in Russia!
speaker: the side-whiskered man

utterance: Tarrarra-boom-de-ay!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Look, I beg you, look at his dog's tricks!
speaker: the side-whiskered man

utterance: Horse's head that you are! Do you mean to tell me that a moujik understands how to fight? A disease he does! He only knows how to strike like a bear [Jake adapted his voice and gesticulation to the idea of clumsiness], an' dot'sh ull! What does he care where his paw will land, so he strikes. But here one must observe rulesh [rules].
speaker: Jake

utterance: Can't you see? America is an educated country, so they won't even break bones without grammar. They tear each other's sides according to 'right and left,' you know.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Nevertheless, I do think that a burly Russian peasant would, without a bit of grammar, crunch the bones of Corbett himself; and he would not charge him a cent for it, either.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Is dot sho? I betch you he would not. The peasant would lie bleeding like a hog before he had time to turn around.
speaker: Jake

utterance: But they might kill each other in that way, ain't it, Jake?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Oh, that will happen but very seldom.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Let it be as you say. My grandma's last care it is who can fight best.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Nice pleasure, anyhull. Never min', we shall see how it will lie in his head when he has a wife and children to support.
speaker: Malke

utterance: What does a chicken know about these things?
speaker: Jake

utterance: And you, Jake, can not do with-out 'these things,' can you? Indeed, I do not see how you manage to live without them.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Don't you like it? I do. Once I live in America,I want to know that I live in America. Dot'sh a' kin' a man I am! One must not be a greenhorn. Here a Jew is as good as a Gentile. How, then, would you have it? The way it is in Russia, where a Jew is afraid to stand within four ells of a Christian?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Are there no other Christians than fighters in America? Why don't you look for the educated ones?
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Do you mean to say the fighters are not ejecate? Better than you, anyhoy. Here you read the papers, and yet I'll betch you you don't know that Corbett findished college.
speaker: Jake

utterance: I never read about fighters.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Then say that you don't know, and dot'sh ull!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Alla right, let it be as you say; the fighters are not ejecate. No, not a bit!But what will you say to baseball? All college boys and tony peoplesh play it.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Ah, you don't answer, shee?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Sure! You must know how to peetch.
speaker: Jake

utterance: And I, for my part, don't see what wisdom there is to it. I think I could throw, too.'
speaker: the presser

utterance: He can do everything!
speaker: Pessé

utterance: How hard can you hit ?
speaker: Jake

utterance: As hard as you at any time.
speaker: the presser

utterance: I betch you a dullar to you' ten shent you can not.
speaker: Jake

utterance: There he goes!-betting! For my part, your pitzers and catzers may all lie in the earth. A nice entertainment, indeed! Just like little children-playing ball! And yet people say America is a smart country. I don't see it.
speaker: the presser

utterance: 'F caush you don't, becaush you are a bedraggled greenhorn, afraid to budge out of Heshter Shtreet.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Look at the Yankee!
speaker: the presser

utterance: More of a one than you, anyhoy.
speaker: Jake

utterance: He thinks that shaving one's mustache makes a Yankee !
speaker: the presser

utterance: 'Pon my vord, I'll ride into his mug and give such a shaving and planing to his pig's snout that he will have to pick up his teeth.
speaker: Jake

utterance: That's all you are good for.
speaker: the presser

utterance: Better don't answer him, Jake.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Oh, I came near forgetting that he has somebody to take his part!
speaker: the presser

utterance: Don't get excited.
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Better don't soil your hands.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Look here, Jake; since fighters and base-ball men are all educated, then why don't you try to become so? Instead of spending your money on fights, dancing, and things like that, would it not be better if you paid it to a teacher?
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Never min' what I do with my money, I don't steal it from you, do I? Rejoice that you keep tormenting your books. Much does he know! Learning, learning, and learning, and still he can not speak English. I don't learn and yet I speak quicker than you!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Ull right, ull right!
speaker: Meester Bernstein

utterance: Vill you go by Joe to-night?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: No.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vy, to-day is Vensday.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: And without you I don't know it!
speaker: Jake

utterance: He does look like a regely Yankee, doesn't he?
speaker: Pessé

utterance: Go and ask him!
speaker: the finisher girl

utterance: Go and hang yourself together with him! Such a nasty preacher! Did you ever hear-one dares not say a word to the noblewoman!
speaker: Pessé

utterance: It is no used! There is not a stitch of work, if only for a cure. Look, look how they have lowered their noses!
speaker: the boss

utterance: Vell, I shall not be teasing you. Pity living things!' The expressman is darn stess. I would not go till I saw him start, and then I caught a car. No other boss could get a single jacket even if he fell upon his knees. Vell, do you appreciate it at least? Not much, ay?
speaker: the boss

utterance: Look at the rush they are making! Just like the locusts of Egypt!
speaker: the boss

utterance: Don't be snatching and catching like that, You may burn your fingers. Go to your machines, I say! The soup will be served in separate plates. Never fear, it won't get cold.
speaker: the boss

utterance: So kvick?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: You cull dot kvick? Good-bye!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Say, ain't you goin' to dance to-night, really?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: I tol' you I vouldn't.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Von, two, tree! Leeft you' feet!
Don' so kvick-sloy, sloy! Von, two, tree,
von, two, tree!
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
What have
we done to be knocked about in this man-
ner?
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Lord of the universe! What a
world this be!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: You don't say!
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Vot you stand like dot?
You vont to loin dantz?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: You a detectiff?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: You vont a job?
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Is
it hot anawff for you?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Yep!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Look at
them!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
But
wait till you get married, too, we
shall see how you will then dance and
jump!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Zents to de right an' ladess to the left!
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
Sawda!
Ull kin's! Sam, you ought ashamed you'-
selv; vy don'tz you treat you' lada ?
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
Goot-evenig, Dzake! I didn't seen you at ull! Say, Dzake,
I'll take care dis site an' you take care dot
site-ull right?
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance: Alla right!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Gentsh, getch you partnesh, hawrry up!
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
Don' bee 'fraid. Gu right aheat an'
getch you partner!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Don' be 'shamed, Mish Co-
hen. Dansh mit dot gentlemarn!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Cholly! vot's de madder mitch you? You
do hop like a Cossack, as true as I am a
Jew
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Dzake, do me a faver; hask Mamie to
gib dot feller a couple a dantzes
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
I hasked 'er myself,
but se don' vonted. He's a beesness man,
you 'destan', an' he kan a lot o' fellers an' I
vonted make him satetzfiet.
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance: Dot monkey?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Vot you
talkin' aboyt! She vouldn't lishn to me nei-
der, honesht.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Say dot you don' vonted and dot's ull.
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
Alla right; I'm goin' to ashk her, but I
know it vouldn't be of naw used.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Never min', you hask 'er foist. You
knaw se vouldn't refuse you!
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
Hoy much vill you bet she will refushe
shaw?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Vot kin' foon a man you are! Ulle-
ways like to bet!
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
F cuss it depend mit vot kin' a mout' you
vill hask, you 'destan'?
speaker: Joe Peltner

utterance:
By gum, Jaw! Vot you take me for?
Ven I shay I ashk, I ashk. You know I
don' like no monkey beeshnesh. Ven I
promish anytink I do it shquare, dot'sh a
kin' a man I am!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Good-evenig, Mamie!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Rats!
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
Shay, Mamie, give dot feller a tvisht,
vill you?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Dot slob again? Joe must tink if you
ask me I'll get scared, ain't it? Go and tell
him he is too fresh
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
Vot you kickin' aboyt, anyhoy? Jaw
don' mean notin' at ull.
If you don'
vonted never min', an' dot'sh ull. It don'
cut a figger, shee?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Look how kvick he gets excited!
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
I ain't get ekshitet at ull; but vot'sh de
used a makin' monkey beesnesh?
speaker: Jake

utterance: You are a monkey you'self
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
An' you are a monkey from monkey-
land
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Vill you dansh mit dot
feller ?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Rats! Vot vill you give me?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Vot should I give you?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vill you treat?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Treat? Ger-rr oyt!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Den I von't dance.
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
Alla right. I'll treat you mit a coupel
a waltch.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Is dot so? You must really tink
I am swooning to dance vit you
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
Look at her, look! she is a regely
getzke *: one must take off one's cap to
speak to her. Don't you always say you
like to dansh with me becush I am a good
dansher?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
You must tink you are a peach of a
dancer, ain' it? Bennie can dance a
sight better dan you
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Alla right!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
So you
don' vonted ?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
O sugar! He is gettin' mad again.
Vell, who is de getzke, me or you? All
right, I'll dance vid de slob. But it's only
becuss you ask me, mind you!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Dot'sh alla right!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
But you makin' too much fush. I like to
shpeak plain, shee? Dot'sh a kin' a man I
am.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Look at the way she is stickin' to
him!
speaker: Miss Jacobs

utterance: You are jealous, ain't you?
speaker: Fanny

utterance:
Who, me? Vy should I be jealous?
On my part let them both go to You must
be jealous. Here, here! See how your
eyes are creeping out looking! Here,
here!
speaker: Miss Jacobs

utterance:
Will you shut your scurvy mouth, little
piece of ugliness, you? Such a piggish
apron check!
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Such a nasty little runt!
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Such a little cricket already knows
what 'jealous' is!
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
You had better go home or your
mamma will give you a spanking.
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
To think of a bit of a flea like that hav-
ing so much cheek! Here is America for
you!
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
America for a country and 'dod'll do'
[that'll do] for a language!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Hello, Fanny!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hello!
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Come, give ush a tvisht, vill you?'
speaker: Jake

utterance: But you ain't goin' by Joe to-night!
speaker: Fanny

utterance:
Go to
your lady, she'll be mad atch you.
speaker: Fanny

utterance:
I didn't vonted to gu here, honesht,
Fanny. I o'ly come to tell Jaw shometin',
an' dot'sh ull
speaker: Jake

utterance: Why should you apologize?
speaker: Fanny

utterance:
As if he was obliged to apologize
to me! For my part you can dance with
her day and night. Vot do I care? As if
I cared! I have only come to see what a
bluffer you are. Do you think I am a fool?
As smart as your Mamie, anyway. As if I
had not known he wanted to make me stay
at home! What are you afraid of? Am I
in your way then? As if I was in his way!
What business have I to be in your way?
Who is in your way?
speaker: Fanny

utterance:
Dot'sh alla right! You will finish
your sermon afterward. And in the mean-
time lesh have a valtz from the land of
valtzes!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
But I don't need it, I don't wish it!
Go to your Mamie!
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Vell, vill you treat, Jake?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Vot you vant, a kish?
speaker: Jake

utterance: May the Angel of Death kiss you! !
speaker: Mamie

utterance:
Once I am treating, both ladas must
be treated alike, ain' it?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
But vy don't you treat, you stingy
loafer you?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Vot elsh you vant? A peench ?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
It's something like a baker, ain't it?
The more cakes he has the less he likes
them. You and I have a lot of girls; that's
`why we don't care for any one of them.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
I hate retail
beesnesh, shee? Dot'sh a' kin' a man I
am!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Alla right, hurry up now!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Righd evay! Righd evay!
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Vot'sh a madder? Vot'sh a madder?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Vot's der madder? What should be
the madder? Wait-a-I don't know what
I can do
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Any bad news? Speak out!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Speak out! It is all very well for you
to say 'speak out.' You forget that one is a
piece of Jew
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Don't bodder a head! I have paid you, haven't I?
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Say, young man, you need not be so
angry. Half of
the letter I have read, have I not? so I shall
refund you one cent and leave me in peace.
speaker: old Jew

utterance:
Tell me what is the matter. Is anybody
dead? Do tell me now.
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Vell, since you know it already, I may
as well tell you. It is your father who has been freed; may
he have a bright paradise.
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Ha?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Was he an old man?
speaker: old Jew

utterance: About seventy
speaker: Jake

utterance:
Seventy? Then he had lived to a good
old age. May no one depart younger
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Good-night!
speaker: Jake

utterance:
I'll see you to-morrow, if God be
pleased.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Good-night!
speaker: old Jew

utterance: I shall not go there to-night, nor any other night,
speaker: Jake

utterance: I will begin a new life!
speaker: Jake

utterance: A weeping to me! The yellow rooster is gone!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Father-in-law, mother-in-law calls you to dinner. Hurry up, Yekl, dinner is ready.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Eshcoosh me, mishesh, be so kind as to lend me your prayer-book. I want to say the night prayer
speaker: Jake

utterance: Are you crazy or drunk? A nice time to make fun!
speaker: the landlady

utterance: May I as surely be alive as my father is dead!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Yekl!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Dot'sh alla right!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Oi a lamentation upon me! He shaves his beard!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Yosselé, look! Here is taté!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Why, it is taté!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: You look like a poritz,
speaker: Gitl

utterance: How are you? How is mother?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: How should she be? So, so. She sends you her love,
speaker: Jake

utterance: How long was father ill?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Maybe a month. He cost us health enough.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Don't!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Here everything is so different.
speaker: Jake

utterance: They don't wear wigs here,
speaker: Jake

utterance: What then?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: You will see. It is quite another world.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Shall I take it off, then? I have a nice Saturday kerchief,
speaker: Gitl

utterance: It is of silk-I bought it at Kalmen's for a bargain. It is still brand new.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Here one does not wear even a kerchief.
speaker: Jake

utterance: How then? Do they go about with their own hair?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Vell, alla right, put it on, quick!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Is this better?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Alla right, leave it be for the present,
speaker: Jake

utterance: Oi woe is me! Why, it is Sabbath!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Two! He ain' no maur as tree years, de liddle feller!
speaker: Jake

utterance: You must be hungry?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Not at all! Where do you eat your varimess ?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Don't say varimess, here it is called dinner.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Dinner? And what if one becomes fatter?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Leave it to me, I know what will become her and what won't. I'll get her a hat that will make a Fifth Avenue lady of her, and you shall see if she does not give in. If she is then not satetzfiet to go with her own hair, vell!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Quite a panenke!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: What is it they call this?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Floor!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: And that?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: And what was it Yekl called that?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Veen-neev-veenda,
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Can't you say veenda? What a peasant head! Other greenhornsh learn to speak American shtyle very fast; and she-one might tell her the same word eighty thousand times, and it is nu used.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Es is of'n veenda mein ich,
speaker: Gitl

utterance: He must hate me! A pain upon me!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Lord of the world! Where am I?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Did I ever tell you I was a tzingle man?
speaker: Jake

utterance: And am I obliged to give you a report whether my wife has come or not? You are not worth mentioning her name to, anyhoy.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Ah, may she be killed, the horrid greenhorn he
speaker: Jake

utterance: Never min', she will oyshgreen herself and I shall get used to
speaker: Jake

utterance: Outside?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Why, do you think I sha'n't go to Joe's, nor to the theatre, nor anywhere any more? Still oftener than before! Hoy much vill you bet?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Rats! A married man, a papa go to a dancing school! Not unless your wife drags along with you and never lets go of your skirts.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Are you Mrs. Podkovnik?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Yes; why?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Nothing. I just want to speak to you.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: What is it?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: As I say, nothing at all. Is there nobody else in the house?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: May I not live till to-morrow if there is a living soul except my boy, and he is asleep. You may speak; never fear. But first tell me who you are; do not take ill my question. Be seated.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: My name is Rosy-Rosy Blank. 'F cou'se, you don't know me, how should you? But I know you well enough, never mind that we have never seen each other before. I used to work with your husband in one shop. I have come to tell you such an important thing! You must know it. It makes no difference that you don't know who I am. May God grant me as good a year as my friendship is for you.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Something about Jake?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: How did you guess? About Jake it is! About him and somebody else. But see how you did guess! Swear that you won't tell anybody that I have been here.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: May I be left speechless, may my arms and legs be paralyzed, if I ever say a word!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Remember, now, not a word, either to Jake or to anybody else in the world. I had a mountain of trouble before I found out where you lived, and I stopped work on purpose to come and speak to you. As true as you see me alive. I wanted to call when I was sure to find you alone, you understand. Is there really nobody about?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: There is a girl; well, her name is Mamie; well, she and your husband used to go to the same dancing school-that is a place where fellers and ladies learn to dance. I go there, too; but I know your husband from the shop.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: But that lada has also worked in the same shop with him, hasn't she?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Why, did Jake tell you she had?
speaker: Fanny

utterance: No, not at all, not at all! I am just asking. May I be sick if I know anything.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: The idea! How could they work together, seeing that she is a shirtmaker and he a cloakmaker. Ah, if you knew what a witch she is! She has set her mind on your husband, and is bound to take him away from you. She hitched on to him long ago. But since you came I thought she would have God in her heart, and be ashamed of people. Not she! She be ashamed! You may sling a cat into her face and she won't mind it. The black year knows where she grew up. I tell you there is not a girl in the whole dancing school but can not bear the sight of that Polish lizard!
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Why, do they meet and kiss?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Tell me, do tell me all, my little crown, keep nothing from me, tell me my whole dark lot.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Ull right, but be sure not to speak to anybody. I'll tell you the truth: My name is not Rosy Blank at all. It is Fanny Scutelsky. You see, I am telling you the whole truth. The other evening they stood near the house where she boards, on Chrystie Street; so they were looking into each other's eyes and talking like a pair of little doves. A lady who is a particla friend of mine saw them; so she says a child could have guessed that she was making love to him and trying to get him away from you. 'F cou'se it is none of my business. Is it my business, then? What do I care? It is only becuss I pity you. It is like the nature I have; I can not bear to see anybody in trouble. Other people would not care, but I do. Such is my nature. So I thought to myself I must go and tell Mrs. Podkovnik all about it, in order that she might know what to do.
speaker: Fanny

utterance: Oi! Oi! Little mother! A pain to me! What is to be done? Lord of the world, what is to be done? Come to the rescue! People, do take pity, come to the rescue!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: My little heart! you don't know what a friend I am to you! Oh, if you knew what a serpent that Polish thief is!
speaker: Fanny

utterance: It serves you right! It is all becuss you will not throw away that ugly kerchief of yours. What is the use of your asking my advice?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Oi! I think even that wouldn't help it now. The Uppermost knows what drug she has charmed him with. A cholera into her, Lord of the world!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Say, will you stop talking nonsense? No wonder your husband does not care for you, seeing these stupid greenhornlike notions of yours.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: How then could she have bewitched him, the witch that she is? Tell me, little heart, little crown, do tell me! Take pity and be a mother to me. I am so lonely and
speaker: Gitl

utterance: What shall I tell you? that you are a blockhead? Oi! Oi! Oi! Will the crying help you? Ull right, cry away!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: But what shall I do?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: It may drive me mad. I won't wear the kerchief any more. this is the last day.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Dot's right! When you talk like a man I like you. And now sit still and listen to what an older person and a business woman has to tell you. In the first place, who knows what that girl-Jennie, Fannie, Shmennie, Yomtzedemennie-whatever you may call her—is after? In the second place, asposel [supposing] he did talk to that Polish piece of disturbance. Vell, what of it? It is all over with the world, isn't it? The mourner's prayer is to be said after it, I declare! A married man stood talking to a girl! Just think of it! May no greater evil befall any Yiddish daughter. This is not Europe where one dares not say a word to a strange woman! Nu, sir!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: What, then, is the matter with him? At home he would hardly ever leave my side, and never ceased looking into my eyes. Woe is me, what America has brought me to!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Don't be crying, my child; he may come in for you. Believe me you are making a mountain out of a fly-you are imagining too much.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Oi, as my ill luck would have it, it is all but too true. Have I no eyes, then? He mocks at everything I say or do; he can not bear the touch of my hand. America has made a mountain of ashes out of me. Really, a curse upon Columbus!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: And how does he behave toward the boy?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Would he were as kind to me!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Then it is ull right! Such things will happen between man and wife. It is all humbuk. It will all come right, and you will some day be the happiest woman in the world. You shall see. Remember that Mrs. Kavarsky has told you so. And in the meantime stop crying. A husband hates a sniveller for a wife. You know the story of Jacob and Leah, as it stands written in the Holy Five Books, don't you? Her eyes became red with weeping, and Jacob, our father, did not care for her on that account. Do you understand?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Take off your hands! Take them off at once, I say!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: You shall wash off your silly tears and I'll arrange your hair, and from this day on there shall be no kerchief, do you hear?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Believe me you are a lump of hunchback, sure; you may-may depend up-upon it! Tell me, now, do you ever comb yourself? You have raised quite a plica, the black year take it! Another woman would thank God for such beau-beau-tiful hair, and here she keeps it hidden and makes a bu-bugbear of herself—a regele monkey!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Do you really think he will like it?
speaker: Gitl

utterance: If he does not, I shall refund your money!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Oi, a health to you!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: And now come, piece of wretch!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Goot-evenik, Mr. Podkovnik! Look what I have brought you: a brand new wife!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: It becomes her like a—a—a wet cat.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Go away, you don't mean it!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Another man would consider himself happy to have such a wife. Such a quiet, honest woman! And such a housewife! Why, look at the way she keeps everything—like a fiddle. It is simply a treat to come into your house. I do declare you sin!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: What do I do to her?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Who says you do? Mercy and peace! Only-you understand-how shall I say it? -she is only a young woman; vell, so she imagines that you do not care for her as much as you used to. Come, Mr. Podkovnik, you know you are a sensible man! I have always thought you one-you may ask my husband. Really you ought to be ashamed of yourself. A prohibition upon me if I could ever have believed it of you. Do you think a stylish girl would make you a better wife? If you do, you are grievously mis-taken. What are they good for, the hussies? To darken the life of a husband? That, I admit, they are really great hands at. They only know how to squander his money for a new hat or rag every Monday and Thursday, and to tramp around with other men, fie upon the abominations! May no good Jew know them!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Do you mean to tell me that you would be better off with a dantz-in'-school girl?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: A danshin'-shchool girl?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Who says I care for a danshin'-shchool girl?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Not at all! God be with you! Who? What? When? I did not mean anything at all, sure. Gitl never said a word to me. A prohibition if she did. Come, Mr. Podkovnik, why should you get ektzited? By-the-bye-I came near forgetting-how about the boarder you promised to get me; do you remember, Mr. Podkovnik?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Talk away a toothache for your grandma, not for me. Who told her about danshin' girls?
speaker: Jake

utterance: What is she whimpering about, the piece of stench!/Alla right, I do hate her; I can not bear the sight of her; and let her do what she likes. I don' care!)
speaker: Jake

utterance: Mr. Podkovnik! To think of a sma't man like you talking in this way!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Dot'sh alla right! I don't care for any danshin' girls. It is a lie! It was that scabby greenhorn who must have taken it into her head. I don't care for anybody; not for her certainly
speaker: Jake

utterance: I am an American feller, a Yankee-that's what I am. What punishment is due to me, then, if I can not stand a shnooza like her? It is nu ushed; I can not live with her, even if she stand one foot on heaven and one on earth. Let her take everything
speaker: Jake

utterance: and I shall pay her as much cash as she asks-I am willing to break stones to pay her-provided she agrees to a divorce.
speaker: Jake

utterance: May you and your Polish harlot be jumping out of your skins and chafing with wounds as long as you will have to wait for a divorce!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: He thinks I don't know how they stand together near her house making love to each other!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Look at the Cossack of straw!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Such a piece of cholera!
speaker: Jake

utterance: I wonder who tells her all these fibs?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vell, what do you want now?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: He says it is a lie. I told you you take all sorts of silly notions into your head.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Ach, would it were a lie!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Children, children! Woe, how you do sin! Come now, obey an older person. Whoever takes notice of such trifles? You have had a quarrel? ull right! And now make peace. Have an embrace and a good kiss and dot's ull! Hurry yup, Mr. Podkovnik! Don't be ashamed!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Vot you kickin' aboyt, anyhoy?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Min' jou on businesh an' dot'sh ull
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vo-vo-vot you keeck aboyt?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: He must think I, too, can be scared by his English. I declare my shirt has turned linen for fright! I was in America while you were hauling away at the bellows in Povodye; do you know it?
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Are you going out of my house or not?
speaker: Jake

utterance: And if I am not, what will you do? Will you call a politzman? Ull right, do. That is just what I want. I shall tell him I can not leave her alone with a murderer like you, for fear you might kill her and the boy, so that you might dawdle around with that Polish wench of yours. Here you have it!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Alla right, you may remain with her!
speaker: Jake

utterance: we shall see!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Mamie, come shomeversh! I got to shpeak to you a lot.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vot's de madder?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: This is not the place for speaking. Let us go to the Grand Street dock or to Seventh Street park. There we can speak so that nobody overhears us.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vot's de madder, Jake? Speak out!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: She must give you trouble.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Ach, Mamielé! My life has become so dark and bitter to me, I might as well put a rope around my neck.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Does she eat you?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Let her go to all lamentations! Somebody told her I go around with you.
speaker: Jake

utterance: But you know it is a lie! Some one must have seen us the other evening when we were standing downstairs. You had better not come here, then. When you have some money, you will send it to me.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Ach, don't say that, Mamie. What is the good of my life without you? I don't sleep nights. Since she came I began to understand how dear you are to me. I can not tell it so well.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Yes, but before she came you didn't care for me!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: I always did, Mamie. May I drop from this roof and break hand and foot if I did not.
speaker: Jake

utterance: It is not what it used to be, Jake. Now that I know you are a married man it is all gone. Yes, Jake, it is all gone! You should have cared for me when she was still there. Then you could have gone to a rabbi and sent her a writ of divorce. It is too late now, Jake.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: It is not too late! I will get a divorce, anyhoy. And if you don't take me I will hang myself.
speaker: Jake

utterance: On a burned straw?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: It is all very well for you to laugh. But if you could enter my heart and see how I shuffer!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Woe is me! I don't see how you will stand it. But I don't understand; since you sent her tickets and money, you must like her.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: All right; but why don't you go to Fanny, or Beckie, or Beilké the " Black Cat"? You used to care for them more than for me. Why should you just come to me?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: All you say is not worth a penny, and it is too late, anyvay. You have a wife and a child; better go home and be a father to your boy.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: You don' vanted? Alla right, you be shorry.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hol on! How are you going to fix it? Are you sure she will take a divorce?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Will she have a choice then? She will have to take it. I won't live with her anyhoy. Mamie, my treasure, my glory! Say that you are shatichfied; my heart will become lighter.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Remember now, Jake! Now it is all settled. Maybe you are making fun of me? If you are, you are playing with fire. Death to me-death to you!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Am I to blame? Who asked you to come? Did I lure you from her, then? I should sooner have thrown myself into the river than taken away somebody else's husband. You say yourself that you would not live with her, anyvay. But now it is all gone. Just try to leave me now! Do you think my heart is no heart?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Don't be uneasy, my dear, my gold, my pearl, my consolation! I will let my throat be cut, into fire or water will I go, for your sake.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Dot's all right. But how are you going to get rid of her? You von't go back on me, vill you?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Me? May I not be able to get away from this spot. Can it be that you still distrust me?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Swear!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: How else shall I swear?
speaker: Jake

utterance: By your father, peace upon him.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: May my father as surely have a bright paradise.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Vell, are you shatichfied now?
speaker: Jake

utterance: All right. But you do think she will take money?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: But I have none.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Nobody asks you if you have. Would she take it, if you had?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: If I had! I am sure she would take it; she would have to, for what would she gain if she did not?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Are you sure?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: 'F cush!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Ach, but, after all, why did you not tell me you liked me before she came?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Again!
speaker: Jake

utterance: All right; wait.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: You will not let yourself be talked away from me?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Not even if your father came to you from the other world-if he came to you in a dream, I mean—and told you to drop me?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: And you really don't care for Fanny?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Nor for Beckie ?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Look, piece of loafer you! But what is the use? It is not light enough, and you can not read, anyway. You can eat, dot's all. Vell, you could make out figures, couldn't you? There are three hundred and forty dollars. It should be three hundred and sixty-five, but then for the twenty-five dollars you owe me I may as well light a mourner's candle, ain' it?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Mamielé, you know what? Let us run away!
speaker: Jake

utterance: You are a fool! I have a better plan. But tell me the truth, did you not guess I had money? Now you need not fear to tell me all.
speaker: Mamie

utterance: An' you didn' vanted?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Sure! I knew all along Jakie was my predestined match. Only he is a great lump of hog, Jakie is. But a heart is a clock: it told me I would have you some day. I could have got lots of suitors-may the two of us have as many thousands of dollars-and business people, too. Do you see what I am doing for you? Do you deserve it, monkey you?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Never min', you shall see what a dansh-in' shchool I shta't. If I don't take away every shcholar from Jaw, my name won't be Jake. Won't he squirm!
speaker: Jake

utterance: Dot's all right; but foist min' dot you don' go back on me!
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Min' je, Jake. This is as good as a marriage certificate, do you understand?
speaker: Mamie

utterance: Ready!
speaker: old Jew

utterance: Young woman! here is the writ of divorce all ready. Now thou mayst still change thy mind.
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: Mind thee, I tell thee once again. Thou must accept this divorce with the same free will and readiness with which thou hast married thy husband. Should there be the slightest objection hidden in thy heart, the divorce is null and void. Dost thou understand?
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: Say that you are saresfied.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Ull ride, I am salesfiet.
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Witnesses, hear ye what this young woman says? That she accepts the divorce of her own free will.
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: Then I must also tell you once more, that this divorce is good only upon condition that you are also divorced by the Government of the land-by the court-do you understand? So it stands written in the separate paper which you get. Do you understand what I say ?
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: Dot'sh alla right. I have already told you that the dvosh of the court is already fikshed, haven't I?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Here is thy divorce. Take thy divorce. And by this divorce thou art separated from me and free for all other men!
speaker: Jake

utterance: You must not forget, my daughter, that you dare not marry again before ninety-one days, counting from to-day, go by; while you-where is he, the young man? Gone?
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: You want him badly, don't you? Let him go I know where, the every-evil-in-him that he is!
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: He may wed even to-day.
speaker: Rabbi Aaronovitz

utterance: What are you crying about, foolish face that you are! Another woman would thank God for having at last got rid of the lump of leavened bread. What say you, rabbi? A rowdy, a sinner of Israel, a regely loifer, may no good Jew know him! Never min', the Name, be It blessed, will send you your destined one, and a fine, learned, respectable man, too.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Really, what are you crying about, Mrs. Podkovnik? You ought to bless the hour when you became free.
speaker: a neighbor

utterance: Ai, you have no papa any more, Joeyelé! Yoselé, little crown, you will never see him again! He is dead, taté is!
speaker: Gitl

utterance: Shurr-r up! You want Mr. Bernstein to leave you, too, do you? No more is wanted than that he should get wind of your crying.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Nobody will tell him. But, anyhull, what is the used crying?
speaker: a neighbor

utterance: Ask her, the piece of hunchback! Another woman would dance for joy, and here she is whining, the cudgel. What is it you are snivelling about? That you have got rid of an unclean bone and a dunce, and that you are going to marry a young man of silk who is fit to be a rabbi, and is as smart and ejecate as a lawyer? You would have got a match like that in Povodye, would you? I dare say a man like Mr. Bernstein would not have spoken to you there. You ought to say Psalms for your coming to America. It is only here that it is possible for a blacksmith's wife to marry a learned man, who is a blessing both for God and people. And yet you are not saresfied! Cry away! If Bernstein refuses to go under the wedding canopy, Mrs. Kavarsky will no more bodder her head about you, depend upon it. It is not enough for her that I neglect business on her account.
speaker: Mrs. Kavarsky

utterance: Really, what are you crying about, Mrs. Podkovnik? You ought to bless the hour when you became free.
speaker: a neighbor
